Posts.Content: Hi Jcu1111, Just wondering if you have any news yet. I certainly recall how excruciating the waiting was. I didn’t have to wait long for the biopsy results but had to wait many weeks for a decision to be reached as to whether I would need chemo. I finally learned that I did need it on Christmas Eve 3 yrs ago. I think Owlgram’s comment about breast cancer not coming in one size fits all is very important to remember. That was certainly news to me when I went through the initial phases of diagnosis, surgery, & treatment. I felt overwhelmingly confused for months with all the options, details, etc. Things will settle down and make more sense to you as time goes by no matter what direction your journey takes you. Despite the challenges and discomforts of chemo, I think those first few weeks post- diagnosis were the hardest. You will most likely learn that there is much cause for hope/optimism and a great deal of encouraging support from the people who provide your medical care. And we are here for you, so let us know how you are doing.
Posts.Title: Just told I have breast cancer.

Posts.Content: What day is your appt? It’s totally normal to feel anxious & expecting the worst. If you are like a lot of us, it will be hard to absorb the information you get on that first appt with the surgeon, so be sure to take someone with you who could take some notes and also ask questions. Ask for clarification of anything you don’t understand. Even if you have cancer and even if there has been some spread to lymph nodes, there is still every reason to be optimistic. I have a number of friends who have had some spread to node(s) and after treatment are doing very well years later. I did not have spread to nodes but had a large tumor in a small breast which put me into Stage 2. I’m doing well 3 yrs after diagnosis. Sending encouraging thoughts your way!
Posts.Title: Just told I have breast cancer.

Posts.Content: I especially loved the cozy prayer shawl knit by friends at my church. One friend brought popcorn and a few favorite movies and a PBS TV series she especially liked and got at the town library. And I always loved it when people came bearing a few flowers or chocolates!
Posts.Title: What’s on your cancer care package wish list?

Posts.Content: I don’t think it is the norm to have scans or MRIs immediately after surgery and chemo. I had a mastectomy for a large tumor and then chemo but had no positive nodes. I did not have radiation and had no scans or MRIs at the completion of chemo. I was scheduled for a breast study every 6 months, with a mammogram alternating with a breast MRI. Make sure you get the breast MRI at least once a year if at all possible. My understanding is that mammograms are not as effective as breast MRIs in finding any spread, but insurances and Medicare won’t normally pay for more than 1 breast MRI/yr due to cost. At least that was the situation in my case. I’d encourage you to pose your question to your Oncologist and see what she/he says about this important issue. Your situation might be different because of your positive nodes. Best wishes to you!
Posts.Title: What tests to ask for after breast cancer surgery and chemotherapy

Posts.Content: When I was diagnosed 3 yrs ago at age 69, I knew next to nothing about BC even though I had had a few friends with it and have a # of drs in my family. I thought BC was BC was BC and had not a clue about all the different types, stages, treatments, etc. After my mastectomy, in our 1st app’t with my oncologist, I was so overwhelmed and confused I didn’t absorb anything! So I started to educate myself through reading and, more importantly, also did what Small-Town-Karen suggested: wrote down my multitude of questions and underlined everything in my surgical & initial diagnostic reports I didn’t understand (which was a ton!!). My subsequent appts w/ my drs and oncology nurse practitioner went MUCH better as my understanding improved. I have Lobular BC, Stage 2 and now actually get what that means! Not that I don’t still sometimes get anxious and fearful as I proceed through my journey, but the information and the great support I get from so many people at my cancer center (and my family/friends) goes a long way in getting me through the challenging times. So just keep asking away !! My very best wishes to you ☮️.
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi Neela13, I was diagnosed with Stage 2 lobular (vs ductal) breast cancer in Oct 2015. I was totally asymptomatic, and it was found on routine mammogram. I underwent a right mastectomy and chose to do no reconstruction. I had no lymph node involvement but had a large tumor which necessitated the surgery. I went through 4 cycles of chemo with quite a few side effects. On general principle my wonderful oncologist does not use the term “in remission” for patients only 3.5 yrs out from diagnosis; she prefers “cancer free.” I am on an estrogen blocker, also called aromatose inhibitor, named Exemastane, for at least 10 years because my particular tumor still carries a fairly high chance of recurrence even with surgery, chemo, and the long term treatment. I was also in a clinical study for 8 months but had to be dropped from that due to complications with my blood counts. In regard to follow-up testing: I have 1 mammogram and 1 breast MRI on my remaining breast per year, alternating every 6 months. I have complete blood work every 6 months. I see my oncologist only once a year now and my oncology nurse practitioner halfway through that period. One year after completion of my chemo, I had a scare with some pulmonary symptoms and had lung scans every 3 mos for a year until it was determined that it was not cancer but rather scarring from earlier infections that was being seen on the scans. That was a scary time! Of course I don’t really know enough about your individual case, but I think if I were in your boots (with Stage 2?) I might get a 2nd opinion as to the need for a little closer monitoring. Most competent, caring doctors aren’t offended by that. I don’t know what that would look like since you don’t have a remaining breast to image, but I would at least wonder about having bloodwork. I, like you, really would have liked more aggressive follow-up, but I suspect much of the hesitancy comes from the fact that even insurance plans with good coverage and Medicare won’t cover such testing. I have read about bio-marker tests, but my doctor did not think that was indicated. Wishing you the very best!
